Learnthebasics.description: CSS or Cascading Style Sheets is the language used to style the frontend of any website. CSS is a cornerstone technology of the World Wide Web, alongside HTML and JavaScript.Visit the following resources to learn more:

resources.name: CSS Crash Course For Absolute Beginners
CSS Masterclass - Tutorial & Course for Beginners

questions.question: What does CSS stand for?
questions.description: Select the option that correctly expands the acronym CSS.
questions.hint: Consider the common expansion of the CSS acronym in web development.

options.label: A
options.description: Central Style System
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct expansion of CSS is Cascading Style Sheets.

options.label: B
options.description: Computer Style Sheets
options.explanation: Not accurate. The correct expansion of CSS is Cascading Style Sheets.

options.label: C
options.description: Cascading Style Sheets
options.explanation: Correct! CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that best describes the main purpose of using CSS in web development.
questions.hint: Consider the role of CSS in styling the presentation of HTML content.

options.label: A
options.description: Handling server-side logic
options.explanation: Incorrect. CSS is primarily used for styling the presentation of HTML content and is not involved in server-side logic.

options.label: B
options.description: Creating and managing databases
options.explanation: Not accurate. CSS is not used for creating or managing databases; its main purpose is styling web content.

options.label: C
options.description: Styling the presentation of HTML content
options.explanation: Correct! The primary purpose of CSS is to style the presentation of HTML content in web development.

questions.question: Which file type is commonly used for external CSS files?
questions.description: Select the option that represents the common file type used for external CSS files.
questions.hint: Consider the file extension commonly associated with CSS files.

options.label: A
options.description: .html
options.explanation: Incorrect. HTML files use the '.html' extension, but it is not the common file type for external CSS.

options.label: B
options.description: .css
options.explanation: Correct! The common file type for external CSS files is '.css'.

options.label: C
options.description: .js
options.explanation: Not accurate. '.js' is the file extension for JavaScript files, not CSS.

questions.question: Where in an HTML document should you link an external CSS file?
questions.description: Choose the correct location in an HTML document to link an external CSS file.
questions.hint: Consider the HTML element used to link external CSS files and its placement within the HTML document.

options.label: A
options.description: Within the <body> element
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct location to link an external CSS file is usually within the <head> element, not the <body> element.

options.label: B
options.description: Within the <head> element
options.explanation: Correct! An external CSS file is commonly linked within the <head> element of an HTML document.

options.label: C
options.description: At the end of the <body> element
options.explanation: Not accurate. While it's possible to include inline styles at the end of the <body> element, linking an external CSS file is typically done within the <head> element.

questions.question: What does the 'Cascading' in CSS refer to?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the meaning of 'Cascading' in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider the hierarchical nature of CSS styles and how they are applied.

options.label: A
options.description: Random order of styles
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'Cascading' in CSS refers to a specific order and hierarchy, not a random one.

options.label: B
options.description: Applying styles without hierarchy
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'Cascading' in CSS involves a hierarchy in which styles are applied based on specificity and order.

options.label: C
options.description: A hierarchical order of styles based on specificity and order of appearance
options.explanation: Correct! 'Cascading' in CSS refers to a hierarchical order in which styles are applied based on specificity and the order of appearance.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to change the text color of an element?
questions.description: Choose the CSS property that is commonly used to change the text color of an HTML element.
questions.hint: Consider the property responsible for controlling text color in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: background-color
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'background-color' is used for changing the background color, not the text color.

options.label: B
options.description: color
options.explanation: Correct! The 'color' property is commonly used to change the text color of an HTML element.

options.label: C
options.description: font-size
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'font-size' is used for adjusting the size of the font, not the text color.

questions.question: In CSS, what does the term 'pseudo-class' refer to?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the meaning of 'pseudo-class' in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider the role of 'pseudo-classes' in selecting and styling elements based on their state or position.

options.label: A
options.description: An imaginary class without any functionality
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'Pseudo-classes' in CSS have specific functionality and are not imaginary.

options.label: B
options.description: A real class with unique functionality
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'Pseudo-classes' are distinct from regular classes and have unique functionality.

options.label: C
options.description: A keyword added to selectors that specifies a special state of the selected element
options.explanation: Correct! 'Pseudo-classes' in CSS are keywords added to selectors to specify a special state of the selected element, such as :hover or :active.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to control the spacing between lines of text?
questions.description: Choose the CSS property that is commonly used to control the spacing between lines of text.
questions.hint: Consider the property responsible for adjusting the space between lines of text in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: margin
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'margin' is used for controlling the outer space of an element, not the spacing between lines of text.

options.label: B
options.description: line-height
options.explanation: Correct! The 'line-height' property is commonly used to control the spacing between lines of text in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: padding
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'padding' is used for controlling the inner space of an element, not the spacing between lines of text.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to make text bold?
questions.description: Choose the CSS property that is commonly used to make text bold.
questions.hint: Consider the property responsible for adjusting the weight of the text in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: font-style
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'font-style' is used for adjusting the style of the font, not the weight or boldness of the text.

options.label: B
options.description: font-weight
options.explanation: Correct! The 'font-weight' property is commonly used to make text bold in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: text-transform
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'text-transform' is used for controlling the capitalization of text, not the boldness.

questions.question: In CSS, how can you select all paragraphs within a specific <div> element?
questions.description: Choose the correct CSS selector to select all paragraphs within a specific <div> element.
questions.hint: Consider the CSS selector that targets nested elements within a specific parent element.

options.label: A
options.description: div > p
options.explanation: Correct! The selector 'div > p' targets all paragraphs directly nested within a <div> element.

options.label: B
options.description: div + p
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'div + p' selects paragraphs that are immediately preceded by a <div> element, not paragraphs within a <div>.

options.label: C
options.description: div ~ p
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'div ~ p' selects paragraphs that are siblings of a <div> element, not paragraphs within the <div>.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'box-sizing' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'box-sizing' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'box-sizing' property affects the sizing calculation of elements in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: It adjusts the color of the box.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'box-sizing' property is not related to adjusting the color of the box.

options.label: B
options.description: It changes the shape of the box.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The 'box-sizing' property is not used to change the shape of the box.

options.label: C
options.description: It alters the sizing calculation of the box, including or excluding padding and border.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'box-sizing' property adjusts the sizing calculation of the box, considering or excluding padding and border.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to add a shadow to an element?
questions.description: Choose the CSS property that is commonly used to add a shadow effect to an HTML element.
questions.hint: Consider the property responsible for creating shadow effects in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: box-shadow
options.explanation: Correct! The 'box-shadow' property is commonly used to add a shadow effect to an HTML element in CSS.

options.label: B
options.description: text-shadow
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'text-shadow' is used for adding a shadow effect specifically to text, not elements.

options.label: C
options.description: border-shadow
options.explanation: Not accurate. There is no 'border-shadow' property in CSS; 'box-shadow' is used for adding shadows.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'float' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'float' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'float' property affects the positioning of an element in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: It makes text bold.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'float' property is not related to making text bold; it affects the positioning of elements.

options.label: B
options.description: It positions an element to the left or right, allowing content to flow around it.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'float' property positions an element to the left or right, allowing content to flow around it.

options.label: C
options.description: It changes the background color of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Changing the background color is not the purpose of the 'float' property.

questions.question: What does the 'z-index' property control in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that correctly defines what the 'z-index' property controls in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'z-index' property influences the stacking order of elements.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the color of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'z-index' property does not control the color of an element.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the visibility of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The 'visibility' property controls the visibility of an element, not 'z-index'.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls the stacking order of elements, determining which one appears on top.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'z-index' property controls the stacking order of elements, determining which one appears on top of others.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'opacity' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'opacity' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'opacity' property affects the transparency of an element.

options.label: A
options.description: It adjusts the font size of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Adjusting the font size is not the purpose of the 'opacity' property.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the spacing between lines of text.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The 'line-height' property controls the spacing between lines of text, not 'opacity'.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls the transparency of an element.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'opacity' property controls the transparency of an element in CSS.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to set the background color of an element?
questions.description: Choose the CSS property that is commonly used to set the background color of an HTML element.
questions.hint: Consider the property responsible for controlling the background color of an element in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: color
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'color' is used for setting the text color, not the background color.

options.label: B
options.description: background-color
options.explanation: Correct! The 'background-color' property is commonly used to set the background color of an HTML element in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: text-color
options.explanation: Not accurate. There is no 'text-color' property in CSS; 'color' is used for text color.

questions.question: What does the 'position' property in CSS control?
questions.description: Choose the option that correctly defines what the 'position' property controls in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'position' property influences the positioning of an element in a document.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the font style of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'position' property is not related to controlling the font style of an element.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the order of list items.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The order of list items is controlled by other properties; 'position' is not related.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls the positioning of an element within its containing element.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'position' property controls the positioning of an element within its containing element in CSS.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to add rounded corners to an element?
questions.description: Choose the CSS property that is commonly used to add rounded corners to an HTML element.
questions.hint: Consider the property responsible for creating rounded corners in CSS.

options.label: A
options.description: border-radius
options.explanation: Correct! The 'border-radius' property is commonly used to add rounded corners to an HTML element in CSS.

options.label: B
options.description: corner-radius
options.explanation: Incorrect. There is no 'corner-radius' property in CSS; 'border-radius' is used for rounded corners.

options.label: C
options.description: curve-radius
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'curve-radius' is not a valid CSS property for creating rounded corners.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'display' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'display' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'display' property influences the layout and rendering of elements.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the text alignment of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Text alignment is controlled by other properties; 'display' is not related to text alignment.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the visibility of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The 'visibility' property controls visibility; 'display' is related to layout and rendering.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls how an element is displayed, affecting its layout and rendering.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'display' property controls how an element is displayed, influencing its layout and rendering in CSS.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'margin' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'margin' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'margin' property affects the spacing outside an element's border.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the spacing inside an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'margin' controls the spacing outside an element's border, not inside.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the spacing outside an element's border.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'margin' property controls the spacing outside an element's border in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls the font size of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Adjusting the font size is not the purpose of the 'margin' property.

questions.question: What does the 'position: relative;' CSS property do?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the behavior of the 'position: relative;' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'position: relative;' affects the positioning of an element.

options.label: A
options.description: It positions the element relative to its normal position in the document.
options.explanation: Correct! 'position: relative;' positions the element relative to its normal position in the document flow.

options.label: B
options.description: It makes the element completely invisible.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Making an element invisible is not the primary purpose of 'position: relative;'.

options.label: C
options.description: It fixes the element's position, so it stays in the same place even when the page is scrolled.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Fixing the position is associated with 'position: fixed;', not 'position: relative;'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'flexbox' layout in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that best describes the purpose of the 'flexbox' layout in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'flexbox' is used for layout and alignment of items in a container.

options.label: A
options.description: It is used for adding shadows to elements.
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'flexbox' is not used for adding shadows; it's a layout model for items in a container.

options.label: B
options.description: It is used for creating responsive typography.
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'flexbox' is not specifically designed for responsive typography.

options.label: C
options.description: It is used for creating a flexible and efficient layout structure.
options.explanation: Correct! 'flexbox' is used for creating a flexible and efficient layout structure in CSS.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used for adjusting the transparency of an element, supporting IE8 and earlier?
questions.description: Choose the CSS property that is used for adjusting the transparency of an element, including support for IE8 and earlier.
questions.hint: Consider the property that provides transparency and has support for older versions of Internet Explorer.

options.label: A
options.description: opacity
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'opacity' is not supported in IE8 and earlier; consider a property with broader compatibility.

options.label: B
options.description: filter: alpha(opacity=50);
options.explanation: Correct! 'filter: alpha(opacity=50);' is used for adjusting transparency and is supported in IE8 and earlier.

options.label: C
options.description: transparent: true;
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'transparent: true;' is not a valid CSS property for adjusting transparency.

questions.question: What does the 'box-shadow' property in CSS define?
questions.description: Select the option that correctly defines the purpose of the 'box-shadow' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'box-shadow' is used to create shadow effects around elements.

options.label: A
options.description: It defines the color of the element's border.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The color of the border is defined using the 'border-color' property, not 'box-shadow'.

options.label: B
options.description: It defines the shadow effect around the element.
options.explanation: Correct! 'box-shadow' is used to define shadow effects around elements in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It defines the size of the element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The size of an element is defined using properties like 'width' and 'height', not 'box-shadow'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'transition' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'transition' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'transition' is used to create smooth animations between property changes.

options.label: A
options.description: It defines the font style of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The font style is defined using the 'font-style' property, not 'transition'.

options.label: B
options.description: It defines the spacing between lines of text.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The spacing between lines of text is controlled by 'line-height', not 'transition'.

options.label: C
options.description: It creates smooth animations between property changes.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'transition' property is used to create smooth animations between property changes in CSS.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'clear' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'clear' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'clear' is used to control the behavior of an element next to a floated element.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the color of the element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The color of an element is not controlled by the 'clear' property.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the visibility of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The 'visibility' property is used for controlling visibility, not 'clear'.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls how an element behaves in relation to floated elements.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'clear' property is used to control how an element behaves in relation to floated elements in CSS.

questions.question: How can you center an element horizontally in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the correct method to center an element horizontally in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider the different techniques used to horizontally center an element.

options.label: A
options.description: text-align: center;
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'text-align: center;' is used for centering text within an element, not the element itself.

options.label: B
options.description: margin: auto;
options.explanation: Correct! 'margin: auto;' is commonly used to center block-level elements horizontally in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: float: center;
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'float: center;' is not a valid CSS property for centering elements.

questions.question: What does the 'line-height' property control in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that correctly defines what the 'line-height' property controls in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'line-height' influences the spacing between lines of text.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the spacing outside an element's border.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The spacing outside an element's border is controlled by the 'margin' property.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the spacing between lines of text.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'line-height' property controls the spacing between lines of text in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls the size of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The size of an element is defined by properties like 'width' and 'height,' not 'line-height'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'max-width' property in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'max-width' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'max-width' is used to limit the maximum width of an element.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the font size of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The font size is controlled by the 'font-size' property, not 'max-width'.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the visibility of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Visibility is controlled by the 'visibility' property, not 'max-width'.

options.label: C
options.description: It limits the maximum width of an element.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'max-width' property is used to limit the maximum width of an element in CSS.

questions.question: What does the 'position: fixed;' CSS property do?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the behavior of the 'position: fixed;' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'position: fixed;' affects the positioning of an element relative to the viewport.

options.label: A
options.description: It positions the element relative to its normal position in the document.
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'position: fixed;' positions the element relative to the viewport, not its normal position in the document.

options.label: B
options.description: It makes the element completely invisible.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Making an element invisible is not the primary purpose of 'position: fixed;'.

options.label: C
options.description: It positions the element relative to the viewport, and it stays fixed even when the page is scrolled.
options.explanation: Correct! 'position: fixed;' positions the element relative to the viewport, and it stays fixed even when the page is scrolled.

questions.question: What does the 'z-index' property in CSS control?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes what the 'z-index' property controls in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'z-index' affects the stacking order of positioned elements.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the opacity of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Opacity is controlled by the 'opacity' property, not 'z-index'.

options.label: B
options.description: It controls the stacking order of positioned elements.
options.explanation: Correct! 'z-index' controls the stacking order of positioned elements in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls the rotation of an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Rotation is controlled by the 'transform' property, not 'z-index'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'pseudo-class' in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that best describes the purpose of the 'pseudo-class' in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'pseudo-classes' are used to define a special state of an element.

options.label: A
options.description: It is used for selecting the first child of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Selecting the first child is achieved using the ':first-child' selector, not a 'pseudo-class'.

options.label: B
options.description: It is used for defining a special state of an element.
options.explanation: Correct! 'pseudo-classes' are used to define a special state of an element in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It is used for creating animated effects.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Animated effects are typically created using the 'animation' property, not a 'pseudo-class'.

questions.question: How does the 'flex-grow' property in CSS work?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes how the 'flex-grow' property functions in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'flex-grow' determines the ability of a flex item to grow.
options: It controls the spacing outside an element's border.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the spacing outside an element's border.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The spacing outside an element's border is controlled by the 'margin' property, not 'flex-grow'.

options.label: B
options.description: It determines the ability of a flex item to grow.
options.explanation: Correct! 'flex-grow' determines the ability of a flex item to grow within a flex container in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It defines the color of the element's border.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The color of an element's border is defined using the 'border-color' property, not 'flex-grow'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'position: absolute;' CSS property?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'position: absolute;' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'position: absolute;' positions an element relative to its nearest positioned ancestor.

options.label: A
options.description: It positions the element relative to its normal position in the document.
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'position: absolute;' positions the element relative to its nearest positioned ancestor, not its normal position.

options.label: B
options.description: It makes the element completely invisible.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Making an element invisible is not the primary purpose of 'position: absolute;'.

options.label: C
options.description: It positions the element relative to its nearest positioned ancestor.
options.explanation: Correct! 'position: absolute;' positions the element relative to its nearest positioned ancestor in CSS.

questions.question: What is the 'box model' in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that best defines the 'box model' in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider the components of the 'box model' and how they contribute to the layout of elements.

options.label: A
options.description: It is a model for creating rounded corners on elements.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Creating rounded corners is associated with the 'border-radius' property, not the 'box model'.

options.label: B
options.description: It defines the structure of a webpage using boxes.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'box model' defines the structure of a webpage by considering elements as boxes with content, padding, border, and margin.

options.label: C
options.description: It is a layout technique for aligning elements in a grid.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Aligning elements in a grid is associated with layout techniques like 'grid' or 'flexbox', not the 'box model'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'rgba()' color notation in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'rgba()' color notation in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'rgba()' is used to define colors with an alpha channel for transparency.

options.label: A
options.description: It defines a color using hexadecimal notation.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Hexadecimal notation is used in the '#RRGGBB' format, not 'rgba()'.

options.label: B
options.description: It defines a color with an alpha channel for transparency.
options.explanation: Correct! 'rgba()' is used to define colors with an alpha channel, allowing for transparency in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It defines a gradient background for an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Gradient backgrounds are defined using properties like 'linear-gradient', not 'rgba()'.

questions.question: How is the 'nth-child' pseudo-class used in CSS?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes how the 'nth-child' pseudo-class is used in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'nth-child' is used to select elements based on their position within a parent element.

options.label: A
options.description: It selects the first child of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Selecting the first child is done using the ':first-child' selector, not 'nth-child'.

options.label: B
options.description: It selects elements based on their position within a parent element.
options.explanation: Correct! 'nth-child' is used to select elements based on their position within a parent element in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It creates a shadow effect around an element.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Creating a shadow effect is associated with properties like 'box-shadow', not 'nth-child'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'display: none;' CSS property?
questions.description: Select the option that best describes the purpose of the 'display: none;' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'display: none;' is used to hide an element.

options.label: A
options.description: It makes an element's text bold.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Making text bold is associated with the 'font-weight' property, not 'display: none;'.

options.label: B
options.description: It hides an element.
options.explanation: Correct! 'display: none;' is used to hide an element in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It creates a flex container.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Creating a flex container is done using 'display: flex;', not 'display: none;'.

questions.question: What does the 'rem' unit in CSS represent?
questions.description: Select the option that correctly defines what the 'rem' unit represents in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'rem' is related to the root font size of the document.

options.label: A
options.description: It represents the width of the viewport.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The width of the viewport is not represented by the 'rem' unit.

options.label: B
options.description: It represents the root font size of the document.
options.explanation: Correct! 'rem' represents the root font size, making it relative to the font size of the root element.

options.label: C
options.description: It represents a percentage value.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Percentage values are represented using '%', not 'rem'.

questions.question: How can you create a responsive webpage layout in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the correct method for creating a responsive webpage layout in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider the techniques used for making webpages adapt to different screen sizes.

options.label: A
options.description: By using fixed-width layouts.
options.explanation: Incorrect. Fixed-width layouts do not adapt well to different screen sizes.

options.label: B
options.description: By using media queries.
options.explanation: Correct! Media queries are used to apply different styles based on the characteristics of the device or viewport.

options.label: C
options.description: By avoiding the use of flexible units like 'em' and 'rem'.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Flexible units like 'em' and 'rem' are often used in creating responsive layouts, not avoided.

questions.question: Explain the CSS 'grid-template-areas' property.
questions.description: Provide an explanation of the 'grid-template-areas' property in CSS and how it is used in grid layouts.
questions.hint: Consider how 'grid-template-areas' allows you to define named grid areas in a grid container.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the gap between grid items.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The gap between grid items is controlled by properties like 'grid-column-gap', not 'grid-template-areas'.

options.label: B
options.description: It defines named grid areas in a grid container.
options.explanation: Correct! 'grid-template-areas' allows you to define named grid areas in a grid container, providing a layout structure.

options.label: C
options.description: It determines the size of the grid columns.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The size of grid columns is determined by properties like 'grid-template-columns', not 'grid-template-areas'.

questions.question: How does the 'transform' property work in CSS?
questions.description: Explain the functionality of the 'transform' property in CSS and its impact on elements.
questions.hint: Consider how 'transform' is used for scaling, rotating, and translating elements in 2D and 3D space.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the layout of grid items.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The layout of grid items is controlled by grid properties, not the 'transform' property.

options.label: B
options.description: It is used for scaling, rotating, and translating elements in 2D and 3D space.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'transform' property is used for applying transformations like scaling, rotating, and translating to elements in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It defines the order of flex items.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The order of flex items is controlled by the 'order' property, not the 'transform' property.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'object-fit' property in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that best describes the purpose of the 'object-fit' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'object-fit' is used to control how content should be resized to fit its container.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the order of stacked elements.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The order of stacked elements is typically controlled by the 'z-index' property, not 'object-fit'.

options.label: B
options.description: It is used for styling form elements.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Styling form elements is achieved using various styling properties, not 'object-fit'.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls how content should be resized to fit its container.
options.explanation: Correct! 'object-fit' is used to control how content should be resized to fit its container in CSS.

questions.question: Explain the 'box-sizing' property in CSS.
questions.description: Provide an explanation of the 'box-sizing' property in CSS and its impact on the sizing of elements.
questions.hint: Consider how 'box-sizing' affects how the total width and height of an element are calculated.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the layout of flex items.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The layout of flex items is controlled by flex properties, not 'box-sizing'.

options.label: B
options.description: It determines the sizing of elements by including padding and border in the calculation.
options.explanation: Correct! 'box-sizing' determines whether the padding and border are included in the total width and height of an element in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It is used for creating animations.
options.explanation: Not accurate. Creating animations is typically done using the 'animation' property, not 'box-sizing'.

questions.question: How does the 'visibility: hidden;' property differ from 'display: none;' in CSS?
questions.description: Explain the difference between 'visibility: hidden;' and 'display: none;' in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how these properties affect the visibility and layout of elements.

options.label: A
options.description: Both properties hide the element, but 'visibility: hidden;' preserves the layout space occupied by the element.
options.explanation: Correct! 'visibility: hidden;' hides the element while preserving the layout space, while 'display: none;' removes the element from the layout entirely.

options.label: B
options.description: Both properties hide the element, and they behave identically.
options.explanation: Incorrect. There is a difference in how 'visibility: hidden;' and 'display: none;' impact the layout of elements.

options.label: C
options.description: Both properties remove the element from the layout, but 'visibility: hidden;' leaves a placeholder.
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'visibility: hidden;' does not leave a placeholder in the layout.

questions.question: Explain the 'position: fixed;' property in CSS.
questions.description: Provide an explanation of the 'position: fixed;' property in CSS and its behavior.
questions.hint: Consider how 'position: fixed;' positions an element relative to the viewport.

options.label: A
options.description: It positions the element relative to its normal position in the document.
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'position: fixed;' positions the element relative to the viewport, not its normal position.

options.label: B
options.description: It positions the element relative to its nearest positioned ancestor.
options.explanation: Not accurate. 'position: fixed;' positions the element relative to the viewport, not an ancestor.

options.label: C
options.description: It positions the element relative to the viewport even when scrolling.
options.explanation: Correct! 'position: fixed;' positions the element relative to the viewport, and it stays fixed even when scrolling.

questions.question: Explain the 'line-height' property in CSS.
questions.description: Provide an explanation of the 'line-height' property in CSS and its impact on text within an element.
questions.hint: Consider how 'line-height' affects the vertical space between lines of text.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the indentation of the first line of text.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The indentation of the first line of text is controlled by the 'text-indent' property, not 'line-height'.

options.label: B
options.description: It sets the vertical space between lines of text within an element.
options.explanation: Correct! 'line-height' sets the vertical space between lines of text, influencing the overall appearance of text within an element.

options.label: C
options.description: It defines the size of the font in em units.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The size of the font is typically defined using the 'font-size' property, not 'line-height'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'transition' property in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that best describes the purpose of the 'transition' property in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'transition' is used to create smooth animations between different property values.

options.label: A
options.description: It is used for specifying the timing function of an animation.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The timing function of an animation is specified using the 'animation-timing-function' property, not 'transition'.

options.label: B
options.description: It is used to create smooth animations between different property values.
options.explanation: Correct! 'transition' is used to create smooth animations by transitioning between different property values over a specified duration.

options.label: C
options.description: It controls the order of stacked elements.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The order of stacked elements is typically controlled by the 'z-index' property, not 'transition'.

questions.question: Explain the 'flex-shrink' property in CSS.
questions.description: Provide an explanation of the 'flex-shrink' property in CSS and its role in flexbox layouts.
questions.hint: Consider how 'flex-shrink' determines the ability of a flex item to shrink.

options.label: A
options.description: It controls the spacing outside an element's border.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The spacing outside an element's border is controlled by the 'margin' property, not 'flex-shrink'.

options.label: B
options.description: It determines the ability of a flex item to shrink.
options.explanation: Correct! 'flex-shrink' determines the ability of a flex item to shrink within a flex container in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It defines the order of flex items.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The order of flex items is controlled by the 'order' property, not 'flex-shrink'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'currentColor' keyword in CSS?
questions.description: Choose the option that best describes the purpose of the 'currentColor' keyword in CSS.
questions.hint: Consider how 'currentColor' is used to represent the computed value of the 'color' property.

options.label: A
options.description: It represents the current font size of an element.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The current font size is not represented by 'currentColor'.

options.label: B
options.description: It represents the computed value of the 'color' property.
options.explanation: Correct! 'currentColor' is used to represent the computed value of the 'color' property in CSS.

options.label: C
options.description: It sets the current position of an element in a layout.
options.explanation: Not accurate. The position of an element in a layout is controlled by properties like 'position', not 'currentColor'.
